When a small group of living beings (a small population) is separated from the main population from which it originated (for example, if it moves over a mountain range or a river, or if it moves to a new island so that it cannot easily return), it often finds itself in a different environment from the one in which it was previously.
This new environment has different resources and competitors, so the new population will need new characteristics or adaptations to be a powerful competitor compared to what it needed before.
The original population has not changed at all, they still need the same adaptations.
Over time, as the new population adapts to its new environment, it begins to look less and less like the other population.
Finally, after thousands or even millions of years, the two populations will look so different that they will no longer be considered to belong to the same species.
We call this process "speciation", which simply means the formation of new species. Speciation is an inevitable consequence and a very important part of evolution.

Technological determinism is a term that encompasses a wide range of ideas in practice, ranging from technological push or technological imperative to a strict sense in which the destiny of humanity is dictated by an underlying logic linked to scientific laws and their manifestation in technology.

Most interpretations of technological determinism agree on two general ideas: the development of technology itself proceeds beyond the influence of cultural and political factors, and technology has an impact on societies conditioned intrinsically rather than socially.
For example, one could say that the automobile necessarily leads to the development of roads.
However, a national road network is not economically viable for a handful of cars, so new production methods are developed to reduce the cost of owning a car.
Massive car ownership also leads to a higher incidence of accidents on the roads, which leads to the invention of new techniques in the field of health care to treat the resulting injuries.

Shipping is by far the most efficient way to transport large quantities of people and goods across the oceans.
Traditionally, the Navy's job has been to ensure that your country maintains the ability to move your people and goods, while interfering with your enemy's ability to move their people and goods.

One of the most remarkable examples of this situation was the North Atlantic Campaign during the Second World War. The Americans were trying to get troops and supplies across the Atlantic Ocean to help Britain.
At the same time, the German Navy, using mainly U-Boats, was trying to stop this traffic.
If the Allies had failed, Germany would probably have been able to conquer Great Britain as it did the rest of Europe.

Ancient cultures and tribes began to keep them close by for easy access to milk, hair, meat, and hides.

Domesticated goats were usually kept in herds that roamed the hills or other grazing areas, often cared for by shepherds who were usually children or adolescents, similar to the more common term of shepherds. These pastoral methods are still in use today.
Wagonways were built in England as early as the 16th century.

Although the wagon ways were simply made of parallel wooden planks, they allowed the horses that pulled them to reach greater speeds and to pull heavier loads than on the slightly more accident-prone roads of the day.
Croissants were introduced early to keep the tracks in place. However, it was soon realized that the tracks would be more effective if they were equipped with a steel band on top.
This has become a common practice, but iron has caused more wear on the wooden wheels of the wagons.
Finally, wooden wheels were replaced by iron wheels. In 1767, the first iron rails appeared.

Their predecessors, the australopiths, did not walk upright as usual.

After its adoption by Congress on July 4th, a handwritten manuscript signed by Congress President John Hancock and Secretary Charles Thomson was then sent to a few blocks away, to the printing shop of John Dunlap.
During the night, between 150 and 200 copies were made, now known as "Dunlap Broadsides".
The first public reading of the document was made by John Nixon in Independence Hall on July 8.
One of them was sent to George Washington on July 6, who read it to his troops in New York on July 9. A copy arrived in London on August 10.
The 25 Dunlap broadsides that are known to exist are the oldest copies of the document. The original manuscript has not survived.

Biological clocks are self-sustaining oscillators that will continue a cycle of functioning for a certain period of time, even in the absence of external stimulation.

Hershey and Chase used phages, or viruses, to implant their own DNA into a bacterium.
They conducted two experiments to mark either the DNA of the phage with radioactive phosphorus, or the protein of the phage with radioactive sulphur.

Traffic flow is the study of the movements of drivers and vehicles between two points, and the interactions they have with each other.
Unfortunately, it is difficult to study traffic flow because the behaviour of drivers cannot be predicted with one hundred percent certainty.
Fortunately, drivers tend to act in a reasonably coherent range; thus, traffic flows tend to have a reasonable coherence and can be represented mathematically in an approximate manner.
To better represent the traffic flow, relationships have been established between the three main characteristics: (1) throughput, (2) density, and (3) speed.
These relationships help with planning, design and operation of roadway installations.

Most insects have the advantage of being able to fold their wings along their body.
This gives them a greater number of small places to hide from predators.
Today, the only insects that cannot fold their wings are dragonflies and mayflies.

At the other end of the spectrum, one transforms into an unrecognizable individual who feels that he/she must change everything that the group has created so far and do things his/her way.

Virtual teams are subject to the same standards of excellence as conventional teams, but there are subtle differences.
Members of a virtual team often function as a point of contact for their immediate physical group.
They often have more autonomy than traditional team members because their teams can meet according to different time zones, which may not be understood by their local management.
The presence of a real "invisible team" (Larson and LaFasto, 1989, p109) is also a unique element of a virtual team.
The "invisible team" is the management team to which each member reports. It sets the standards for each of them.

The solution is provided by technology in the form of virtual field trips. Students can view ancient artifacts in a museum, visit an aquarium, or admire a beautiful work of art while sitting with their class.
Participating practically in an excursion is also an excellent way to reflect on a trip and share your experiences with future generations.

For example, students from Bennet High School in North Carolina design a website each year about their visit to the state capital. Each year, the site is updated, but the old versions are kept online to serve as an album.

Blogs can also help students improve their writing skills. Even though students often try blogging with a careless grammar and spelling, the fact that they have an audience usually improves the situation.
As students are often the most critical audience, the blog author begins to try to improve his writing to avoid criticism.
In addition, blogging "forces students to better know the world around them." The need to generate interest from the public encourages students to be intelligent and interesting (Toto, 2004).
Blogs are a tool that stimulates collaboration and encourages students to extend their learning beyond the traditional school day.

The modern city of Casablanca was founded by Berber fishermen in the 10th century BCE, and was used by the Phoenicians, the Romans, and the Merinides as a strategic port called Anfa.
The Portuguese, who after having destroyed it, rebuilt it and baptised it Casa Branca, finally abandoned it in 1755 after an earthquake.
The Moroccan sultan rebuilt the city under the name Daru l-Badya, and it was renamed Casablanca by the Spanish merchants who established trading posts there.
Casablanca is one of the least interesting places in all of Morocco for shopping.

Around the old medina it is easy to find places where you can buy traditional Moroccan products, such as tagines, pottery, leather goods, hookahs and all sorts of souvenirs, but that's all for tourists.
Goma is a tourist town located in the extreme east of the Democratic Republic of Congo, near Rwanda.
In 2002, Goma was destroyed by the lava from the volcano Nyiragongo which buried most of the city's streets, particularly the city centre.
Although Goma is reasonably safe, any visit outside of Goma should be researched to understand the state of the ongoing fighting in the North Kivu province.
The city is also the starting point for the ascent of the volcano Nyiragongo as well as for treks among the cheapest gorilla treks in Africa.
You can use boda-boda (motorcycle taxi) to get around Goma. The normal (local) price is about 500 Congolese francs for a short ride.
Combined with its relative inaccessibility, "Timbuktu" has become a metaphor for distant and exotic countries.

It was one of the main stops on Henry Louis Gates's PBS series Wonders of the African World.

The Kruger National Park (KNP) is located in northeastern South Africa and borders the Mozambique border to the east, the Zimbabwe border to the north and the Crocodile River forms the southern border.
The total area of the park is 19,500 km2, which is divided into 14 ecozones, each with its own unique fauna.
It is one of the most famous theme parks in South Africa and considered the jewel of South Africa's national parks (SANParks).
As with all South African national parks, there are daily entrance and conservation fees for the park.
It may be advantageous to purchase a Wild Card which gives access to some South African parks, as well as all South African national parks.
Hong Kong Island gives its name to the territory of Hong Kong and is the main attraction for many tourists.

The vast majority of urban development on Hong Kong Island is concentrated on the reclaimed land on the northern shore.

The Sundarbans are the largest coastal mangrove forest in the world, stretching 80 km (50 miles) from the coast to the hinterland of Bangladesh and India.
The Sundarbans have been designated as a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The part of the forest located on Indian territory is called Sundarbans National Park.
Forests, however, are not composed solely of mangrove swamps: they also contain some of the last remnants of the majestic jungles that once covered the Ganges plain.
The Sundarbans cover an area of 3,850 km2, of which about a third is covered by wetlands/marshes.
Sundarbans is a nature reserve since 1966, you can find about 400 Bengal tigers and 30,000 spotted deer there.

The Oyapock Bridge is a cable-stayed bridge. It spans the Oyapock River to link the towns of Oiapoque in Brazil and Saint-Georges-de-l'Oyapock in French Guiana.
The two towers rise to a height of 83 m; it is 378 m long and has two lanes 3.5 m wide.
The vertical clearance under the bridge is 15 meters. The structure was completed in August 2011, but it was not opened to traffic until March 2017.
The bridge should be fully operational by September 2017, when the Brazilian customs posts should be completed.
The Guaraní were the largest indigenous group inhabiting what is now the eastern Paraguay, living as semi-nomadic hunters and practicing subsistence agriculture.
Other indigenous tribes that populated the Chaco, such as the Guaycurú or the Payaguá, survived primarily through fishing, hunting, or gathering.
In the 16th century, Paraguay, once called "the giant province of the Indies," was born from the meeting of Spanish conquerors and indigenous populations.
The Spanish inaugurated the period of colonization, which lasted three centuries.

The official currency of the Falkland Islands is the Falkland Pound (FKP) whose value is equivalent to a pound sterling (GBP).
Money can be exchanged at the only bank on the islands located in Stanley, opposite the FIC West store.
The pound sterling is a commonly accepted currency throughout the islands, while at Stanley, credit cards and U.S. dollars are also often accepted.
On nearby islands, credit cards are unlikely to be accepted, even if it is possible that British and American currencies will be. Speak to the owners in advance to agree on a payment method.
It is almost impossible to exchange money from the Falklands outside the islands, so change it before leaving the islands.

The stirrups are footrests for the rider, which hang on either side of the saddle.
They offer greater stability to the user, but they can pose a safety problem: in fact, the user's feet can get stuck in them.
If a rider is thrown from a horse, but has a foot caught in the stirrup, he could be dragged if the horse runs away. To minimize this risk, a number of safety measures can be taken.
First of all, most riders wear riding boots with a heel and a smooth, narrow sole.
Then, some saddles, notably English ones, have safety bars that allow a stirrup to fall off the saddle if it is pulled backwards by a rider who falls.

Europe is a relatively small continent, but composed of many independent countries. In normal circumstances, travelling through several countries means having to make several visa applications and passport checks.

Violent weather is the generic term for any dangerous meteorological phenomenon that can cause damage, serious social disruption or loss of human life.
Extremely unfavourable weather conditions can occur anywhere in the world, and they can be of several types, depending on the geographical, topographical, and atmospheric characteristics.
Violent winds, hail, excessive rainfall and fires are forms and effects of violent weather, just as thunderstorms, tornadoes, hurricanes and typhoons.
Extreme weather phenomena, regional and seasonal, include cold fronts, snowstorms with strong winds, and sandstorms or dust storms.
It is strongly advised to travellers to research the risks of bad weather that may affect their destination region, knowing that this may have an impact on their planned itineraries.

Japanese work culture is more hierarchical and formal than that to which Westerners may be accustomed.
The costumes are traditional work clothes, and employees are called by their family name or their job title.
Harmony at work is crucial, because it emphasizes collective effort rather than praising individual accomplishments.
Workers are often required to get approval from their superiors for any decision they make and are expected to obey their superiors' instructions without question.
